subject: Re: [junit] Missing API: Assert.assertThat(boolean) or 	IsCollection.isEmpty()
msgSnippet: ... Wow--that s remarkably evocative for an API!  :-) When this assertTrue(b)/assertThat(b) becomes the _only_ reason to go back to the old assertion API s,
messageBody:
On Fri, May 15, 2009 at 2:26 PM, Pigneri, Rocco <rpigneri@...> wrote:
> David,
>
>
>
>>Is the intent less clear in
>
>>
>>assertTrue(list.isEmpty())?
>
>
>
> I wouldn't say that the intent is less clear, but having to go back to
> the "old" assert methods for this one case seems very messy to me.  In
> my mind, Hamcrest is a completely new way to write all the JUnit
> asserts.   Having to go back to assertTrue makes me wonder what other
> features of the old asserts are not replicated in Hamcrest.  In
> addition, it reminds me of how much I didn't like old assert model J,
> particularly how I could never remember where the expected and actual
> values went in the assertEqual functions J (back when I first learned
> JUnit, Eclipse hadn't yet been invented, and we coded in Emacs using the
> old JUnit test runner from 3.x).

Wow--that's remarkably evocative for an API! :-)

When this assertTrue(b)/assertThat(b) becomes the _only_ reason to go
back to the old assertion API's, I'll feel more strongly about this
argument. To get there, hamcrest will need better mismatch reporting,
to fully replicate what JUnit does on strings and arrays. I
understand they're working on that.

David Saff
